SAHARA ARCHAEOLOGICAL QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Planner Recreation and Social Life

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the last few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

How many of these were bachelor's houses?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Not too many.

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? All days while employed.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon etc.? Meals on the Mound kept late at night.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly?

(that is, was the term to "make polite" used, or was some other expression common?)

The invitations varied in their formality.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have bees? When groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

Can't give dates. Try for local. But I helped to build little red barns, which are all the rope for the homestead days.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst it was more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.?

No just to go when came on discovery.

To enjoy the holidays.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHITECTS QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Planar Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor or homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Out to dinner?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? All days? Or only when invited?

4. Were you often invited to other homes? Or was most visiting done without an invitation?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity?

Tell what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe—

Was there any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc., if you have not described these on the school questionnaire.) Give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Was it built by Public Improvement

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you contribute to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other gatherings, etc.? )

10. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize? Generally two, & Betty.

What dances were popular?

11. Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Not to my knowledge.

Card Play. You can still pay that $7.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc.)

If you have not described these on the school questionnaire, give dates.

How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. Then was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Was it built by public subscription?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you have to go to town to have fun? Or did you have enough to name two or three halls for all gatherings, etc.? )

Other things to know to make our study of the hall worth its name - the main activity of all activities around the hall.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

How were babies and small children provided for?

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Was there card playing for a prize?

What dances were popular?

Was there any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Poveshell was very favorable to Carl Playa. You can still pay that $7.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as Glenns and Bates when calling, calling cards, visits, treated ceremonially in parties, etc.? 

Everybody was on the same level.

No, there was no class system.

13. Was the chivalry known in your community? 

Describe what you remember about chivalry, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

Merry old time dances in Franco

and card playing at different houses.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember; telling of any games or entertainments not already mentioned that were popular at parties and socials, and describe how they were played and when some change in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND VESTIGES.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

In 1917 Butte County Homemakers' Club formed.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community?

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

When was it organized?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.

22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families," "Whist" or other, shoveling or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

Put to much Time. The children were tired after playing too much.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, reptiles or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

Not to my knowledge.

PIONEER AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

The Commemorative Club

26. Who organized it?

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

Was Community.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

1910

29. What were the amusements at the picnics you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

All kinds of games

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

Each family took their own lunch

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Tea, milk, salad & sandwiches

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

Around 11 a.m. Had to get home (day) early for chores.

Not to my knowledge.

Give year and month if possible.

26. The organized club.

Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

All kinds of games.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

Each family took their own lunch.

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Tea, milk, salads & sandwiches.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

Around 11 A.M. It was very hot. Had to get home early and go to chores.
33. Describe any features of this phone which you remember as outstanding.

Picnics were held at various times. Because they were held in the summer, they were more likely than at other times.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family picnics, etc., and what types of activities, food and drink, were held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (tennis, baseball, football, etc.).

37. For what games was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving dates of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities, played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Then was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

January 1912. Built from wood. Used for skating, curling, hockey, and other winter sports.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Then was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Around 1912. Built from natural field in Rubenfield, until opened by Mr. Murray & Hockey Association for both hockey & curling. But a great sport! When older...
